I like this is a new role, makes sense, but I worry about the co-existence with elasticsearch. Maybe we just add a check to ensure they can't run side by side?

My reason for that is migration. It seems like we can copy what we did with all the previous elasticsearch ones, where we just bump from one release to the next, keeping data in the same place, with no nasty copy or move required.

So when you enable OpenSearch, we could look to delete the Elasticsearch containers, a bit like when we disabled some of the older monasca services. We could then just make them both default to a docker volume called elasticsearch?

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
The header of the commit message should be a single line, ideally not longer than 50 characters. In this case "Fix address_scope calculation" would seem fine. Then add an empty line and then you can describe your patch in more detail, while keeping a line lenght limit of 80 characters.

Also make sure that you only have a single Change-ID in the commit message, in this case keep the one in line 9 below, otherwise gerrit will be confused.
This should be on multiple lines and not really long.

openstack subnet create --ip-version 4 --network provider --dhcp --host-route  destination=200.201.0.0/24,gateway=200.201.0.1 --subnet-range 200.201.0.0/24 provider1-v4

#6 - self-service network
openstack network create self-service

#7 - self-service subnet
openstack subnet create --ip-version 6 --subnet-pool default-pool-ipv6 --network self-service --ipv6-address-mode dhcpv6-stateful --ipv6-ra-mode dhcpv6-stateful self-service-v6
openstack subnet create --ip-version 4 --network self-service  --dhcp --host-route  destination=192.168.0.0/24,gateway=192.168.0.1 --subnet-range 192.168.0.0/24 self-service-v4

#8 - create router
openstack router create router1

#9 - add self-service subnet as an interface on the router

openstack router add subnet router1 self-service-v6

#10 - Add the provider network as a gateway on each router.

#11 - create bgp speaker

openstack bgp speaker add network bgpspeaker provider

what would happen here if it is dual stack and both (ipv4 + ipv6) are part of address scope? ext_net_id will be share by both and will be overwritten?

Hi Luis,
If both are configured they will be returned on the map, but the address scopes and subnet pools are separated by IP version (ipv4 or ipv6), neutron does not support both in the same context.
The networks connected to bgpspeaker have subnets that can be connected to ipv4 and/or ipv6 address pools. In case there is more than one subnet in the bgpspeaker network if one has an address scope and the other does not, the ext_net_subnetpool_map of the subnet that has an address_scope will not be returned.

As far as I understand they will not be reported in duplicate, address_scopes v4 will be reported by bgpspeaker IP version 4, and address_scopes v6 will be reported by bgpspeaker IP version 6.

tests/unit/test_gerrit.py.message:
I've analyzed this locally and I'm convinced it's okay and we can skip this test in the multi-scheduler case.

I thought that we only ran a single fake gerrit webserver, but we actually start the fake webserver in the fake connection, and you're right that each scheduler gets a new fake connection.  Since the second fake connection/web server doesn't have the checker added (see line 481), it can't find the uuid to report.

If I add the checker to the second fake server, it works as expected, but then fails because it's actually reporting to a different webserver.  Because of this, I don't think it's worth turning my local work into a real patch.

I think the real solution to this is to have a dedicated fake gerrit class with a webserver, and have the base test class set that up for each unique gerrit it sees in the configuration.  All of the fake server-side stuff should move to that class.  That would make our fake gerrit connection subclass much smaller, which will be nice.

This makes me still thinking why this is working with a single scheduler. I think that the test case (self.fake_gerrit) gets a dedicated fake connection which is different from the one the first scheduler gets, but that would mean that we could still have the problem that the connection that handles the event is not aware of the check. Unless there is something that prevents the fake connection of the first scheduler to handle the event and thus ensures that the test case itself handles it.
Thanks for investigating. So if I understand this correctly it's only a testing problem and it's OK to skip this test. I will update the change accordingly.

Need some more thoughts for some of the comments.

Do we just need the variable to directly inject extra firewall rule ? I've not yet fully understood the benefit and requirement to expose the internal data file/interface.

It'd make sense if we want to apply rules gradually instead of applying these by a single run but in that case what we want would be the ability to change name of the yaml file so that the items injected by the previous runs are kept and merged.
Let's create a tripleo_nftables_snippet module - that may provide some better control over the snippets.

With the new tripleo_nftables_snippet, we should be covered. Note that it won't prevent file replacement, since it would also mean "prevent file update" in case rules are changed upon a day-2 operation.

we don't have the same meaning for "3rd parties" - but the idea is to let tripleo-ansible roles write those snippets, yes.

Using file will ensure no random var is needed nor may be overridden at any point. And it makes the whole thing far, far easier to do.

With your example, you're basically describing the exact thing this change is allowing... We're just not providing an interface from within tripleo_nftables (I really don't think this is necessary) - but that's the idea.

the goal here is to allow 3rd parties to inject snippet in a specific location, holding the rules they need to actually work.

For instance, with this, in the standalone context (see the tripleo_compute_node for instance), this will allow tripleo_nova_libvirt, tripleo_nova_migration_target and other compute related ansible roles to inject their different rules, on the remote nodes (compute-1, compute-2, ...) directly at the "configure" stage.

You can probably get a better understanding by checking the follow-up patch here:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/863146

though it's not finished yet, I need to gather service ports/accesses first.

IMO we better avoid letting 3rd parties to inject the raw file but the file should be created by the module in tripleo-ansible. This allows us to even change the data format in the future in case we need any format change.

For example, we can add the variable to tripleo-firewall role to customize the name of the file generated. Then each role can call the role with its own file name then the rules added by different run should be kept every time. This does not require direct access to internal data.

- tripleo_nftables will only look at those files - no more tripleo_nftables_rules is involved

doc/source/release-notes/2104.rst.message: What do you mean by this? It sounds like the user should upgrade the charm but you also say "Before upgrading".
Re-phrased it a bit, see if is clearer.

Sorry for my ignorance of previous discussions but what's our stance on tgt?

If it's supported after the upgrade, what's the point of switching the default this time? On the other hand, if we say lioadm is the new default and the only supposed helper, does it actually make sense to recommend keeping the old default as tgt during the charm upgrade and after?

cinder-lvm is known as SPOF of data by nature so recommending shutting down VMs with LVM volumes and switching the helper during the upgrade might make sense although it's too drastic. I'm not sure booting up the VM actually can use the new helper or not without any manual intervention though.

So, tgt is being sunset in favor of lio since from long ago. LIO is a kernel based implementation and has mostly performance benefits. What triggers this change here is that after Wallaby, the Cinder package changed to bring lio, not tgt as a dependency anymore[1]. So, new Wallaby+ installations will fail if we don't verbosily set this to 'lioadm' (thats because, confusingly, cinder code (not the package) still uses tgtadm as it default).

Upgrading customers will have tgt installed (from the previous cinder dependency), so setting that to tgtadm and not uninstalling the package will guarantee that current attachments will continue to work.

So, I think the best recommendation we should give to customers is:

New customer/cloud:  use lioadm
Upgrading customer: continue to use tgtadm

If for some reason, the upgrading customers want to sunset tgtadm and use lioadm, they can follow the steps below, which were mentioned 'optional' for this reason.

Finally, customers could de-tach all volumes, set lioadm as the helper and that would work, but the cost is high, and the solution I put below would work that around.
__________
[1] https://git.launchpad.net/~chris.macnaughton/ubuntu/+source/cinder/commit/?id=7a58fa04458232caffb50788938cb6d0b3d06f25

Assuming that the charm is not updated, this needs to reference running this command against the cinder-lvm backend. As written, I think it refers to run the config option change and then run the `sudo apt-mark manual tgt` on the same machine where I run the juju cli.

The way our project creation works is an automated tool triggers the gerrit and gitea apis to make the project. Then if you don't set a seed repo we make an empty repo with a .gitreview file that can push code to it. If you do this then you will have to push and review all of the tricircle content in whatever way makes sense for you. The alternative is to make a seed repo and import that entire repo as is. If you want any history or just want to avoid needing to push many changes to bootstrap this is the prefered method.

The opendev admins do this to avoid needing to manually force push for you. We do not want to do this. Instead you should set the seed repo and start that way or go through pushing and merging changes normally.

nodepool/cmd/nodepoolcmd.py.message: Instead of calling the command "disable" why not call it "hold"?

It might be a good idea to only allow a transition from the HOLD state to the READY state to avoid accidentally allowing a node to be reused while another job is still using the node.

This may not be sufficient though as we can disable a node and set it to HOLD before a job compeletes as well. It is more difficult to enforce the state change to HOLD though as you would race the next job starting if you want to only allow READY -> HOLD.

It might also be a good idea to to restrict this to static nodes or require a --force type flag to apply these state changes to ephemeral nodes. This way it is more difficult to accidentally perform a state change on the wrong sort of node.

We should actually just delete the node and let the driver handle processing it.  In the case of the static driver, the node will be re-registered.

This means you can drop the "enable" command entirely and use "delete" in your workflow.

Having to delete a node in order to move from "hold" to "ready" sounds very counter-intuitive. At the very least that would need to be very explicitly documented as the expected workflow. For user-friendlyness I would like to see a "unhold" command matching the "image-pause/-unpause" pair, even if it is only an alias for "delete".

That sounds good to me; at least in the case of static nodes that is in line with what I had in mind for this feature.
But I'll let James have the final word here of course

> This may not be sufficient though as we can disable a node and set it to HOLD before a job completes as well

When I tested it, this was not possible. I don't know the exact mechanism behind it in nodepool but it looked like a node is locked during a job execution and hence can't be disabled


> It might be a good idea to only allow a transition from the HOLD state to the READY state to avoid accidentally allowing a node to be reused while another job is still using the node.

I agree that could be a good safeguard but when testing it, it was not possible to interrupt an ongoing build. I could only test it with static nodes.

Looking at James' comments, I think it makes sense to drop the 'enable' command altogether


> It might also be a good idea to to restrict this to static nodes 

I like this idea but how do I get information about the node type or the corresponding driver?

I think it's okay to allow the 'hold' command for any node type.  It would let someone grab a min-ready node and use it for something.  Then they can delete it.

It's true that you can't go from in-use to hold because the client is expected to hold the lock for the entire time the node is in-use.
Fair point. That should be enough for our use-case still

Making sure I understand the proposed workflow here. Users would hold a node, then when any required work is done delete the node. In the case of ephemeral cloud nodes that frees the resources to be used by a new node. In the case of a static node the static driver will recreate the static node as ready?

If I've understood correctly then I think this will work well.

Is there a reason this needs to be blocking for the delete command?
Is it okay to not have it blocking for the hold command?

Overwriting the state from "in-use" to "hold" doesn't seem like a good idea. On the other hand, as an operator of a busy setup I would really like to be able to issue the hold command while the node is in use and then have nodepool wait until the node is unlocked in the background and apply the hold after that. No idea how to actually implement that, but that's the way I'd like to see this work.
I would very much prefer not having to modify the config in order to perform maintenance. Also, would removing an in-use node from the config actually be safer?

> Overwriting the state from "in-use" to "hold" doesn't seem like a good idea. 

As far as I can see, this is not possible as the node will be locked when it's in use.

> I would really like to be able to issue the hold command while the node is in use and then have nodepool wait until the node is unlocked in the background and apply the hold after that.

This was part of my first idea/draft as well but it was deemed unsafe as it would possibly introduce a race condition with other node requests.
Quoting James: 
> i would not recommend that workflow. you will be racing nodepool itself. in that case i would recommend removing the node from the config file.
If I'm following correctly, trying to delete a locked node is now non-fatal?  Or am I missing something?  If not, then I don't think that's a change we should make.
Similarly to deleting, it seems like if we are unable to lock a node, the command should exit non-zero?
I think I was confused about that earlier.  Now that I understand that this is a ZK lock timeout and not a test timeout, I think this is fine.

However, delete() and hold() behave slightly differently when locking a node: delete() will be blocking, leading to a TimeoutException while hold() is non-blocking and will cause a ZKLockException. Not sure what is the best behavior here but maybe it is okay like this?

My understanding (and I haven't run this locally to double check, so correct me if I'm wrong) is that the current code will raise an exception if we run "nodepool delete" on a locked node.  Raising the exception will cause the CLI to exit rc=1.  And some versions of this patch do the same for the "hold" command, which I think is the best behavior, but my concern with this version is that it would only print a statement that the node was locked and then exit rc=0 because the exception was suppressed (and the same applied to delete).

Anyway, to be clear, I think the best behavior for both delete and hold is to try to lock the node and exit with an error code if that fails.
Not sure if I understand. I don't see the delete function or any other command return non-zero anywhere.

> the current code will raise an exception if we run "nodepool delete" on a locked node.  Raising the exception will cause the CLI to exit rc=1

I see now, I thought you were referring to some explicit return 1 or something like that in the code.
PS15 should behave as you describe now, exiting with an error if locking a node fails

Got it, I changed it now. But with blocking=True, we are back to a TimeoutException in one of the test cases which you commented on earlier. So I don't really know how to improve this if you're not happy with the test

Is there any reason they should be different?  I would think that the current behavior for "delete" should be fine for both: blocking for 5 seconds.  That means if we can't obtain the lock within 5 seconds we give up.  The reason for that is to increase the chance that this succeeds even if one of the system components briefly locks the node for some purpose (they are permitted to do that).

In short, absent a compelling reason otherwise, I think we should just use the existing delete behavior for both commands.

Also, this is a bit of a nit, but this method isn't really necessary and it keeps tripping me up when I look for what else is using it, so if you make a new patchset to resolve the locking situation, maybe you could just move this to the hold() method.
Nit: this method is not necessary, and this should just be the "hold" method.

nodepool/tests/unit/test_commands.py.message: Consider setting the timeout flag to the command here so that we can reduce the length of the timeout. That will make this test run more quickly.

Yes, because the max-servers value set in node.yaml is 96. The nodes list value is initially satisfied via min ready configuration of 1 for fake-label. Then when a new request comes in nodepool cannot fulfill that request using the existing node because its state is HOLD. Nodepool proceeds by provisioning a new node instead since it has max-servers headroom to do so. If it didn't have max-servers headroom it would pause and wait for space to become available.
I suggest s/disable/hold/ so that it's more clear what this does.

Is there something we can do for this assertion other than waiting for a test timeout?

Maybe the command should return immediately (exit code 1) if it can't lock it.  That's probably better for user experience.
When I change the hold command to not have the lockNode invocation blocking, I think I get the expected exception that you were referring to, namely npe.ZKLockException

I think it would actually be good if the command waited for a locked node a reasonable amount of time (for example to finish a job) and afterwards set it to hold, hence the addition of the timeout flag to this command.

Hey all,

Do we have enough of a consensus to move this forward?
Thanks,

Ade

I agree to go with this because of seeing other options we have currently for FIPS testing. For centos stream, we already discussed even with centos stream team and decided to test it in periodic was as that is something we can keep a voting job in gate.

If we get any other distro open license tp test FIPS we can update our testing but meanwhile let's start the testing with this.

I don't want to let the perfect be the enemy of the good here.  It's better to have the FIPS jobs running than not running (e.g., see [0]), and when having them running it's desirable that they be running on the same platform as other CI jobs so we can easily compare results.  So at the present time, that means running Ubuntu in FIPS mode.

It seems like third-party CIs could also consume this secret, and given that most of them run Ubuntu for easy comparison with upstream CI results, that shouldn't be too difficult to do.

The alternative would be to get everything running in something like Rocky Linux or Debian (where FIPS would be free), but that doesn't seem like a reasonable short-term goal.

So my opinion is that we should move forward with this now so we can have both FIPS and non-FIPS CI coverage, because we do want OpenStack to be able to run on FIPS platforms.

[0] https://bugs.launchpad.net/os-brick/+bug/1967790

IMHO, this is massively better than the alternatives of (a) not having any FIPS coverage and (b) having to use CentOS-Stream to get it.

There are other ways to test for FIPS issues if we need to debug these jobs, although I do not think we're likely to end up with difficult FIPS-specific issues that require more in-depth local troubleshooting.

That, and we've been very quick to make FIPS jobs non-voting when issues arise, and I would think we'd continue that behavior with these, especially if it's something non-trivial to address.
My preferred solution in the current situation would be for someone to run these jobs in a 3rd party CI.

Shouldn't the TC really make the call on this?

"Truly open source software is not feature or performance limited. There will be no “Enterprise Edition”." [1]

That FIPS is only tested on what is essentially an "enterprise edition" seems to be skirting too close to this for me to put +w on this by myself...

Technically, OK +2 in that this should work and is probably slightly better than plain-text in code (so every github bot finds it) or slightly obfuscated in code (base64 encoded or something; c.f. first point).

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/opens.html

This isn't the first secret for less open things that openstack has added (the github mirror sync secret is the classic example). I think it is ok to add this secret and use it to figure out if this can be made to work or is otherwise feasible. Openstack should consider Frickler's concerns if this becomes something that openstack wants to require or test broadly though.

To me, this sounds too non-open and sets a bad precedent, this isn't what I would see as open development. It also raises questions like "how would we need to restrict access to held nodes using this secret?".

I would prefer us to not follow this path.

> It seems like third-party CIs could also consume this secret, and given that most of them run Ubuntu for easy comparison with upstream CI results, that shouldn't be too difficult to do.

Note, I'm not sure this is true for two reasons. The first is that encryption keys are not shared by CI systems. Second is I'm not sure if we've been given permission for other CI system to use the key?

> 
> The alternative would be to get everything running in something like Rocky Linux or Debian (where FIPS would be free), but that doesn't seem like a reasonable short-term goal.

Ubuntu runs Firefox out of a snap which makes using tools like selenium for browser content testing difficult. Horizon has been looking at switching jobs that use selenium over to Debian in response to this. Not directly related, but wanted to call out another location where this has become helpful.

> Shouldn't the TC really make the call on this?

Two of us have voted - I'm not sure we need anything too formal, but we can highlight it to the rest of them to see if they want to comment.

> "Truly open source software is not feature or performance limited. There will be no “Enterprise Edition”." [1]

We're looking to use ubuntu's offering for this because it's the closest to the rest of the jobs we have. We've tried on Centos Stream, which is totally free, but other issues with that distro have made it challenging. We could test it with debian, but we just recently had problems with that job (mostly because it's not our primary, IMHO). The ubuntu entitlement is more of a support/certification thing, and I'm pretty sure OpenStack's mission has always been friendly to freely-available software with paid vendor support :)

To me, this is a convenience to do the thing we want to do, which is test with FIPS enabled. There are other ways to do it, we've explored one already, and the pain from that has led us here.

-1 for... discussion? Here it goes:

You summarized the algorithm really well in the commit message, and then I got to the code and was lost all over again :( I wonder if we can simplify it down the the following (all in a single method hopefully) - tell me if I got something wrong:

-1. The hash ring is a thing that takes a list of nodes and a list of nova-compute services, and distributes the former into buckets of the latter. If called multiple times with the same inputs, it will return the exact same outputs. IOW, in a situation where multiple nova-compute services are doing their refresh and calling on the hash ring, they will get the same buckets of nodes.

0a. Re-frame _refresh_cache() as a method that accepts:
  - the hash_ring
  - list of instances that we manage (IOW, instance.host == CONF.host), and returns a list of nodes that we manage (or more precisely, a dict of nodes that we manage, keyed by node UUID).
  - I don't think we need the list of UP compute services... see later.

0b. If the above is true, start with an empty node cache, and just add to it, using the following logic:

1. If the node has an instance on it that we manage, add it to our node cache and set its compute_node.host.

Otherwise:

2. If the hash ring says we're the node's host:

Add it to our node cache, and set its compute_node.host to ourselves. If it has an instance on it, set instance.host to ourselves.

This is where you currently have the "is the node's previous host up?" check, the idea being, if the previous host went away, came back, and started its _refresh_cache() after us with a different list of UP compute services that includes itself (whereas our list didn't include it), it will re-appropriate itself the node. But that's... fine? If there's an instance on the node, once we set instance.host, step 1 will prevent any re-appropriation. And if there's no instance, other hosts are free to take this node from us in the future.

3. If the hash ring says we're not the node's host":

Do nothing.


All of this also has the advantage of squashing your patch on top into this one, into a single, hopefully more easily grokkable, fix?

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Not quoting the previous discussion because syncing back to it was getting difficult to follow. So, service startup adds the entry as in essence the very first step, so the compute node would show back up in the list, so the current revisions with the detection of mismatch would at least skip actions for both computes and instances. Which means startup time really doesn't factor into this whole thing.

So, a single process or even multi-process rapid restart wouldn't trigger a rebalance, but it would trigger the cache being regenerated and reconciliation to occur regardless for nodes assigned to that compute node. If by chance something is wrong, that pass would correct it too, which is a bonus I guess.

The case where a rebalance would occur is if someone stops one or more compute services for >90 seconds.

I guess this leads to a question I've been pondering... Do we, instead of reconciling, if we identify a possibility of the hash ring changing, raise an internal exception to abort the cache/hash ring regeneration... I feel like that would delay overall full reconcile operation if someone is doing some invasive operations like... upgrading services or stopping everything and restarting one service at a time. The other downside which comes to mind to completely short circuiting the cache rebuild/reconciliation process would create a situation where we would be far more likely to match the compute node host not found in service list condition state which forces operators like Chris presently get to deal with.

Going back to invasive restarts, in that case, there would be record churn, but rightfully so because we can't make assumptions to the operators intent or the infrastructure state.

(Maybe, a doc update is worthwhile here, suggesting to do quick restarts if found necessary.)

And, the window to identify a necessity to rebalance would be only at every resource tracker run.

It occurs to me that we likely need to direct operators to be careful with CONF.update_resources_interval since by default it's value is 0, which could create tons of pain... I actually wonder if we should log a warning if this is the case....

> > -1 for... discussion? Here it goes:
> 
> Okay, wow, this is a bit much. But okay!

Sorry, I realize this was an unfriendly way to start a review. In the past just leaving comments on Nova patches would often result in no reaction, so I've developed a habit (and been advised by others) to be a bit "in your face" about it, and not feel bad about saying "-1 for question visibility". Which is what I attempted to do here, just clumsily. Sorry again.

> > You summarized the algorithm really well in the commit message, and then I got to the code and was lost all over again :( I wonder if we can simplify it down the the following (all in a single method hopefully) - tell me if I got something wrong:
> > 
> > -1. The hash ring is a thing that takes a list of nodes and a list of nova-compute services, and distributes the former into buckets of the latter. If called multiple times with the same inputs, it will return the exact same outputs. IOW, in a situation where multiple nova-compute services are doing their refresh and calling on the hash ring, they will get the same buckets of nodes.
> > 
> 
> Semi-correct, at least based on how I interpret your explaination. The way the hash ring works is based upon just the list of services which are responsible entities in the context. Physical machines, nodes, because everything is a node, unless it is an inode (yes, this is an awful joke).
> 
> Anyway, the way it works is the hash ring *can* contain one or more hosts which *are* responsible for the input node value based upon the input. When self.hash_ring.get_nodes(physical_node_key) is called, it determines based upon the state of the hash ring, which "nodes as in hash ring members", are responsible for the node. So as long as the list responsible services does not change, then if the same data is fed in for each node, the assignment will always be the same. At least, that is now I understand it. If a "responsible entity" disappears or is no longer able to manage a node or take work, then it should disappear from the ring, and upon the next cache refresh, the nodes which were managed by that instance would now be managed by the others. Similarlly if an entirely new "responsible entity" enters the picture. Nodes would be completely re-balanced across all of the responsible entities. This is in part because both the node list and the running compute list are dynamic... ?unicorns?.

I think we have the same concepts in our heads, just worded differently. It doesn't help that the hash ring uses "nodes" for responsible entities, while Ironic uses "nodes" to mean the objects being assigned to the responsible entities. Using the hashring vocabulary, it's telling us which which nodes are responsible for which objects, so get_nodes(<object>) will return one of more nodes. Using the Ironic vocabulary, Ironic is passing Ironic nodes in place of <object>, and gets back a list of nova-services. Let's further hammer it in by making an ASCII table:

  Concept                   Ironic word            Hashring word
  
  responsible entities      nova-compute services  nodes
  objects being mapped      nodes                  objects/data
  what get_nodes() returns  nova-compute services  nodes

> > 0a. Re-frame _refresh_cache() as a method that accepts:
> >   - the hash_ring
> >   - list of instances that we manage (IOW, instance.host == CONF.host), and returns a list of nodes that we manage (or more precisely, a dict of nodes that we manage, keyed by node UUID).
> 
> What value do you perceive by *not* performing the query inside the cache refresh method?

I meant it in a more conceptual sense of "this is the input data that the method's logic operates on. The data can be pulled inside the method's implementation in whatever order is best.

> We've previously learned that doing it *before* getting the list of nodes results in out of sync node caches versus compute records, and compute nodes getting dropped. Hence saga's fix which starts at line 851 which was to move the query until after the list of nodes is retrieved. Previously the instance list was performed first before a list of nodes was collected.
> 
> Why is this important, timing unfortunately. The DB query doesn't take very long at all. But downloading even just a thousand node records takes a non-insignificant amount of time. We've made this better in Ironic, but all of the conversions, and pagination, can make things really painful. I've got some anecdotal numbers on this if your curious and want to cringe at the scale a single nova-compute is attempting to support.
> 
> (Side note, maybe we should count and actually start issuing some rather... urgent errors when people start running things at unreasonable scales...)
> 
> Okay, so to do this, we would need to make get_available_resource and get_available_nodes, get_info, and node_is_available all aware of the hash ring and the list of instances. I guess we could, but then the question is, will we be able to backport this at that point?

I totally buy your explanation of why _get_node_list() takes forever and needs to be done first.


> >   - I don't think we need the list of UP compute services... see later.
> > 
> 
> 
> We need a list of UP compute nodes in order to know if a node is part of the ring in terms of being an active participant in the cluster's management. In other words, if we're based on the presence of down, then we're not actively a redundant service, we're relying on external and likely human driven intervention to resolve conditions. Anyway, I'll separately look at the comments below as I digest everything here.

I keep flip-flapping on this, but I'm still not convinced that using the hashring as the absolute source of truth is bad. IIUC, the reason we need to have a list of nova-compute services that are present and up is the following situation:

0. nova-compute service A is managing node K, with instance X on it.
1. nova-compute service A goes away
2. Rebalance is triggered
3. Hash ring assigns K to nova-compute service B.
4. B saves K in its node cache, updates X's instance.host record, and updates K's compute_node.host record.
5. Surprise, A comes back roughly at the same time as steps 3 and 4 are taking place.

The initial idea was to make steps 3 and 4 conditional on A not having appeared back to avoid B "stealing" its node K and instance X. But what if we don't do that, and just let the process continue:

6. Rebalance is triggered.
7. Steps 3 and 4 repeat, potentially with different values for A, K and X.

I realize this would mean instances and nodes moving across hosts more often, but wouldn't this make this code less fragile and prone to races?

> > 0b. If the above is true, start with an empty node cache, and just add to it, using the following logic:
> 
> 
> So, nodes do need to disappear from the cache if they are no longer in the deployment. Baremetal machines are deleted or removed from a state where they can no longer be provisioned. They may return, but we don't know that an an attempt to deploy to that node would result in a failure. Plus get_available_nodes uses the cache instead of spending the 15 minutes in a medium sized deployment to pull the list of nodes.

So if I understand you correctly, rebuilding the node_cache from scratch every time is not an option, because it takes too long?

> > 1. If the node has an instance on it that we manage, add it to our node cache and set its compute_node.host.
> 
> 
> So basically line line 867-870 w/r/t the node cache.
> 
> My follow-up patch does the latter, disjointed in part because of the complexity and necessity of fixing the hash ring behavior overall. What is present today is... well. yeah. ;)

I was hoping that it we can simplify the algorithm and make it easier to reason about it, we can do everything in the same patch.

> > Otherwise:
> > 
> > 2. If the hash ring says we're the node's host:
> > 
> > Add it to our node cache, and set its compute_node.host to ourselves. If it has an instance on it, set instance.host to ourselves.
> 
> Okay, like 877-889, although the only difference there is if, and only if the hash ring has changed.
> 
> I guess, the difference is I'm trying to avoid the impact to the db which would be potentially having to check the compute node and instance record data for every node in the list of nodes every time the cache is refreshed. I guess I'm trying to avoid a few thousand individual selects in the entire process.

So instance.save() is nice in that it won't actually write anything to the database if nothing has changed on the object. But yeah, we may still need to do the "hash ring has changed?" check for performance reasons. ComputeNode.save() does not have this magic, btw...

> > This is where you currently have the "is the node's previous host up?" check, the idea being, if the previous host went away, came back, and started its _refresh_cache() after us with a different list of UP compute services that includes itself (whereas our list didn't include it), it will re-appropriate itself the node. But that's... fine? 
> 
> Totally fine and also expected behavior. We know from reports of race conditions and missing compute nodes, that we loose compute node records if we get out of sync (in part, because of the host record, again, next patch). The thought at play here was more of one: We know operators will restart one or more compute services in rapid succession, lets make sure we don't needlessly squash on each other, and with a longer set of nodes to iterate through, depending on timing we may have a more observable gap in the window between the original hash ring state and the next hash ring.

But... compute services shouldn't go away if they're restarted. Nova has the CONF.service_down_time and CONF.report_interval configurables that can be tweaked so that, for example, if a nova-compute services takes 15 minutes to restart, it doesn't show up as flapping down then back up while doing so (though it would mean *actualy* service downs take longer to be noticed).

> >If there's an instance on the node, once we set instance.host, step 1 will prevent any re-appropriation. And if there's no instance, other hosts are free to take this node from us in the future.
> 
> This is where we need to make sure the nodes disappear when no longer present in the deployment, which is why the cache rebuild goes through the entire list it can see and bases the decision on the hash ring state.
> 
> > 
> > 3. If the hash ring says we're not the node's host":
> >
> > Do nothing.
> > 
> > 
> > All of this also has the advantage of squashing your patch on top into this one, into a single, hopefully more easily grokkable, fix?
> 
> I... guess, but some of what your suggesting would re-introduce a shift in cache presence awareness on cache updates because we wouldn't be evaluating the absolute latest instance list, but a potentially out of date instance list while we retrieved nodes. Granted, if we've seen it before not a big deal, but get_available_nodes and such would also begin to get outdated info from the cache as we're not refreshing the entire cache, only adding at that point.

I wasn't proposing getting the services first, then the nodes. Get the nodes if that takes longer, then get the services, then use the hash_ring (without adding ourselves to it to ensure consistency across all calls to the hash_ring across all nova-compute services) as the absolute source of truh

> 2. If the hash ring says we're the node's host:

I guess, the difference is I'm trying to avoid the impact to the db which would be potentially having to check the compute node and instance record data for every node in the list of nodes every time the cache is refreshed. > 
> This is where you currently have the "is the node's previous host up?" check, the idea being, if the previous host went away, came back, and started its _refresh_cache() after us with a different list of UP compute services that includes itself (whereas our list didn't include it), it will re-appropriate itself the node. > 
> 3. If the hash ring says we're not the node's host":
>
> Do nothing.
> 
> 
> All of this also has the advantage of squashing your patch on top into this one, into a single, hopefully more easily grokkable, fix?

I... guess, but some of what your suggesting would re-introduce a shift in cache presence awareness on cache updates because we wouldn't be evaluating the absolute latest instance list, but a potentially out of date instance list while we retrieved nodes. Granted, if we've seen it before not a big deal, but get_available_nodes and such would also begin to get outdated info from the cache as we're not refreshing the entire cache, only adding at that point.

I find this concept very complex!
At CERN we only run a nova compute per conductor group.

Now, if we lived in the perfect world:
With the ironic driver, "nova-compute" is basically a proxy to Ironic, and if we were doing it from scratch, there's no need have the instances mapped to a nova compute node. In my view any compute node with the ironic driver should be able to handle it.
Sure, most likely this means a profound refactor in nova-compute (also the cell conductor) and possible some assumptions (maybe not mix kvm and ironic compute nodes in the same cell).

This is definitely a pain point for operators and is hard to clean up when things go wrong, esp. when there are a few thousand nodes involved. After several issues we eventually disabled the rebalancing from our deployment (trading availability/flexibility for predictability/stability). Getting this fixed would be great!

We have the same problem. While inventory is rebalanced between running computes, the instances never gets taken over by a running compute. This causes any actions on the instance to fail. This is a good thing to fix. 

Thanks for doing the hardwork julia. i am happy to review this.

We manage 1000's of ironic BM nodes per region and the issue being addresses here is a constant issue for us. Artom raised some good points, but I am more than excited to see this patch. Addressing these node behaviors will save us many hours a week troubleshooting / recovering nodes.

Granted, a nova contributor has stated in the change set dialog that they would prefer a breaking interface redesign over the needful which has been proposed by other contributors in the past. This case, just happens to be very well notated inline.

A breaking, non-backportable change, which would surely result from a specification process, which would mean operators will not see a fix for potentially years down the road until they manage to get to the newest version. Meanwhile, they would be unable to manage deployed baremetal nodes depending on what they do to their compute cluster or what way it breaks, meaning they would need to perform database surgery to remedy their records and their deployment. Granted, I'm not opposed to merging/backporting a bug fix and then having a dialog on what nova would ultimately like to do if that is the consensus and support from the nova community on doing so, but a -2 seems like an explicit statement that it is not an option.

nova/virt/ironic/driver.py.message:
So current state of the code, *does* pull a compute node list and validates against that as well. If the node is online, then it skips doing anything on an instance level. Deleted compute nodes in the resource tracker are re-created, and actually we'll now in my latest version actually undo deleted state which can occur... say from changing a conductor group setting on a known deployed node.

Which leaves disabled, and upon looking at the use of disabled, it basically, from what I can tell mainly only guards the logic around scheduling. This led me to consider "what if we impacted the hash ring with disabled" and I concluded that was likely a mistake because virt drivers seem to largely not halt internal operations or even ability to do things on a compute node as a result.

Anyway, I'm going to mark this resolved as I think this has been guarded reasonably while trying not to set ourselves up for excesive queries on clusters with thousands, tens of thousands, or even hundreds of thousands of compute nodes.

The plus side with all of this is that any hash ring change will actually remedy the issues we tend to run into, which I guess is a good thing in the long run.

Consider a StarlingX 'standard' system with say 2 controller nodes and 100 worker nodes.  Would the user need to log-in and run the NIC firmware tool manually on each of the 100 worker nodes?

Currently in StarlingX, (any NIC vendor) firmware updates must be uploaded/run manually on each node.  That is, there is no integration with any of the 'system host-device-modify' / 'system host-device-image-upload' to do this once from the active controller --- pushing out the updates to all of the worker nodes.

The reason I ask is I wonder if this would be a useful integration feature.

Agree with Steve that scalable automation of the NIC firmware update should at least be identified as a "Future Enhancement".

i.e. not only for large 'standard' systems as Steve noted,
     but ALSO for Distributed Cloud scenarios where there are 1,000 AIO-SX (single server with a Marvel NIC) StarlingX clouds ... applying a firmware update in this environment needs to be automated or likely won't get done.
     

Starlingx provides such firmware automation for one device, Intel's N3000,
see:
- MANUAL N3000 Firmware Update
https://docs.starlingx.io/node_management/kubernetes/index-node-mgmt-kub-5ff5993b9c60.html#hardware-acceleration-devices
and
- ORCHESTRATION OF N3000 Firmware Update across all hosts of a cloud 
https://docs.starlingx.io/updates/kubernetes/index-updates-kub-03d4d10fa0be.html#n3000-fpga-firmware-update-orchestration
and
- ORCHESTRATION OF N3000 Firmware Update across all subclouds of a Distributed Cloud System
https://docs.starlingx.io/dist_cloud/kubernetes/index-dist-cloud-kub-95bef233eef0.html#fpga-device-image-update-management

Hi Steven and Greg

Sorry for taking long time in providing responses. We were focused on getting drivers upstreamed into Linux kernel.
Now we are back to integration with stx now.

For Octeon software update, our high level requirements are as below
1. any update on Octeon should not require reset of the host.
2. any update on one Octeon device should not require bringing down other Octeon cards in the same host in case of servers with multiple Octeon cards.
3. to be able to update Octeon devices on multiple nodes remotely through operator or similar solution.

Our current approach (under development) to meet these requirements is: 
1. driver integration into the base (stx)
1.1. add support for network other devices, because Octeon shows up as Network/Other device.
1.2. controller is responsible to create VFs and configure device plugins.
2. develop Octeon update tool that can run in a container environment.
3. this tool (collection of Marvell utilities) will update the Octeon device through a PCIe interface.
4. controller/operator to schedule this container based on CRD to update the devices.

Thanks Rajat for your thorough review and for picking up on originally discussed issue of backups blocking live migrations. The intention actually was to "just" fix this particular issue, but then the idea to fix the serialization issue in a broader sense came up and we received positive feedback among the devs.

To my understanding a spec is somewhere in between an issue, a user-story or a requirement and then the particulars of implementing it.

But sticking with the issue of backups actually happening independently from other actions on a volume - would getting cinder to allow just this to work independently be a more viable change? Maybe the initial issue deserves another discussion among the cores to find a less change-heavy alternative?

Just to bring up the numbers we played with when initially discussing the issue of backups blocking a live migration (re-attachment of the volume).... image an 8TB volume being backed up in full. Even with 1GB/s this volume will take 2,5hrs to be backed up - now imaging the user triggering yet another backup or multiple volumes being backed up... 

So decoupling this from a state machine perspective (since it already is for most drivers / implementations which work via snapshots) seems to still make a lot of sense.

Thanks a bunch for picking up on the discussion about this spec during the PTG (https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/antelope-ptg-cinder#L294) ... I'd like to answer your question from the PTG here:

The idea behind this spec was to NOT fix just the issue of backups being blocked, but to allow for other tasks to run in parallel as well.

But fixing "just" the backups blocking other action would be more than helpful and certainly "enough". As explained in this spec migrations only work if the volume is somewhat "idle" (`in-use`, `available`,...) in regards to other operations on it.

And making migrations tolerant about the volume status would start with the extension of the "expected" status for reservations  .. https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/commit/ad184ca698d4b9cce912fcc1e936ef02c44b47d9/cinder/volume/api.py#L2372 to allow volumes in a status of backing up to be moved with their instance. But then we have two processes on the same volume trying to go through their state machine (the backup with "backing-up") and the attachment_reservation with "reserved") ... this is exactly the reason for this bigger proposal to avoid such interwoven state-machines.

But if "just" allowing backups and their state to be independently and if this is the agreed way to approach the issue of live migrations being blocked I am fine with that. This will then likely be about making just the backups and their status NOT using the status field anymore and getting their independent state (machine).

Should we propose a new spec with "just" the backup issue or rephrase this one then?

specs/zed/move-task-status-to-dedicated-.message:
on the same volume?
would be good to be explicit here that we're talking about the same volume/resource
we need to be careful about which tasks are mutually exclusive i.e. can run in parallel and which should be serialized to ensure we don't have race conditions.

Cinder does this on purpose to not allow multiple actions being taken on a volume at the same time. Changing this will lead to pain and suffering.  As someone that operates several large deployments of cinder, I don't want to have to debug problems due to multiple actions being taken on a volume at once.  This is a bad idea.

Maybe it was not clear from the spec but the spec only proposes that only one other specified operation can run concurrently on the same volume. This is why the split up of the status is done. The base actions, such as attaching, change the status, actions such as backing_up change the task_status. But in general only one base operation and one independent operation can run on the volume, resulting in two distinct state machines (please have a look at the state machines included in the spec)
volume backups typically happen against a snapshot/clone of an attached volume.  So the backup process doesn't block the volume being detached after the backup has started.

But this is currently happening when a volume backup is created. As described in the use case or in the mentioned blueprint (https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/move-task-status-to-dedicated-field) the status is checked for a specified status which does not include the migrating status (see: https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/commit/3e048975d0f75b983c69974945f8e5a9792c488a/cinder/volume/api.py#L2112) when the attachment is reserved.

As you have mentioned because the backup-process happens on a snapshot/clone and is handled by a different driver such a task can run as a separate tasks because it does not affect the volume itself.

The example I can see throughout the use case is parallel operation of instance block live migration and creating a backup. are there any other cases that benefit from this additional task field?
I would very much like to see a table of all the operations mapped with other operations that can be performed in a mutually exclusive way and hence benefit from this task field.

we already have fields for attach_status and migration status[1] fields in volume but we use it in combination with the status field.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/objects/volume.py#L99-L100
can't we do both of these with a single ``reset task_status`` endpoint like we do for other resources.

what happens if a volume delete request is issued at this point? since the volume is available, the delete goes through, then how are we going to block the volume deletion until the migration or backup is completed?

Also this can be done without the task_field. if the purpose is to live migrate and backup at the same time, just change migration_status to migrating and status to backing-up.

nova and glance rely on volume status field for states like attaching, detaching, extending etc when waiting for cinder to complete an operation and same case in tempest waiters. This is clearly a massive change and the developer of the cinder change needs to account for all the changes that needs to be done all across OpenStack to adhere to the new behavior else it will break cinder's compatibility with any service that request the latest microversion.
this is a huge effort across multiple projects and without any dedicated assignee, i see no point in accepting the proposal.
Almost all of existing tempest test related to volumes needs to be modified as the waiters currently check for states like creating, attaching, detaching, extending etc

I would describe here that:
1) With the new microversion nova will *always* evacuate the instance to SHUTOFF state.
2) The only way to keep the instance state after the evacuation is to use an older microversion.

Consistency is one benefit. The other is that if the instance is on a downed compute, it's already "off". If the evacuate is performed by the admin and it suddenly becomes running again, that may be a surprise to the actual owner. So, if I have an application running somewhere that has some inbuilt HA stuff, it notices that one instance stops responding and respawns that work elsewhere. Then some admin comes along, trying to help, and evacuates the original to a running state, that may conflict with my replacement instance at best, and at worst, could result in some unexpected data sharing/corruption.

So, since the evacuation is generally not done by the owner of the instance, the thinking is that it's safer (and more consistent) to have it evacuated to off state, like it was (probably) on the dead compute and let the owner do what they want with it.

there are a few reasons

one is the other host died so there might eb data currption or other fallout so its safe to evacuate to off so that the enduser can take remidial action if they want/need too.

second is that if you have a trusted plathform there may be keys other then the volume encyption key that the guest will try to retrieve that may be in acceable if the vm was started by the admin.

that was shaid's orginal usecase not encypted volumes.

the final reason was to save power. some vms are left active when not needed anymore, aws and other public clouds have this problem more then a private cloud.

so by evacuating to off we are not wasting energy on dormant vms.

so in general it was prefered to just always evacute to off in the new microversion.

If this is something specific for how neutron/os-vif are doing things, I'd rather keep it out of the ovsdbapp reference implementation if at all possible.

It seems like os-vif and neutron should just decide who is in charge of creating/deleting these specific bridges. When we talked about this earlier, it sounded like it was going to be possible to just have neutron let os-vif handle vhostuser bridge creation/deletion. Did that not work out?

Thanks for your review. I see and understand your point. I just want to have a discussion over code on the best way to fix this issue. I invited Rodolfo to comment. I just fixed pep8 issues in PS2. I invite you to -1 it again to record your disagreement. Let's see what Rodolfo has to say

In general, we try to avoid setting specific external_ids in ovsdbapp. Its job is to allow users to set the things they want in the database, not force them into specific paradigms. Normally if os-vif/neutron wanted to set/read these values, they'd just go ahead and do that on their own outside of ovsdbapp.

With that said, I'm always a bit skeptical when I see multiple processes or machines relying on timestamps. Especially with OVSDB since there can be a significant delay between two different connections getting updates from the server.

I seem to remember looking at the os-vif code and thinking that for vhostuser it could handle the create/delete of the Bridge, then in neutron since we would know whether or not it was vhostuser we could just not create/delete in that case and not have to worry about synchronization. But that was also a while ago, and I realize I haven't looked at this issue nearly as much as the rest of you. ;)

This is just a revert.

This is another case of "In Neutron the MTU is mutable, is Nova it isn't", in the same vein as https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/852367/1

Instead whacking a bunch of moles, maybe we should just figure out how to properly support mutable MTUs in Nova?

It was discussed during the nova-neutron session and we agreed that in general there is no way to make MTU mutable in nova thus we should update Neutron docs to warn users that updating MTU for network is not as easy for vms (see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-lib/+/862284 for that). But we also agreed to continue with this patch as it can address some valid use case mentioned in the related bug.

Right, Nova *could* update the network's MTU in our cache. What I'm saying is that currently, Nova considers the MTU immutable, and makes no provisions for updating it, ever. Not in the metadata, not in the instance XML. I'm proposing that we take a more holistic approach to solving this by giving Nova proper mutable MTU support (though it could get ugly when it comes to updating the instance XML). If we *just* address the metadata part, it's incomplete, and doesn't solve the other related problems.

I've added an item to the Antelope PTG etherpad to discuss this.

But IIUC nova can update network's mtu in own cache and provide new value in the metadata. The problem in the related bug is that when mtu is provided with metadata, it is stored in the netplan's config file and then mtu provided by dhcp is ignored.
As cloud-init works only during the OS boot the initial mtu value is never updated in the netplan's config.

could this cause problems in nova too? I mean nova records that a VM uses UUID1 mdev then the hypervisor changes that UUID1 now means a different device (different PCI parent). Will this cause that a totally different mdev ends up being attached to the VM after a hard reboot?

I.e. do nova also needs to start tracking the PCI parent of the mdev?
Thanks for the explanation. So conflicting UUID is not a realistic problem today.

I don't think Nova being impacted because we don't use mdevctl for creating the mdevs and we rather directly call sysfs for creating a mdev, which then provides a specific UUID if we don't pass one : 
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/ef18d36bf81755e5cca6e5257355eddfa938b615/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L8182

I agree that it's fragile, I've witnessed it first hand when I broke stuff trying to regenerate the domain XMLs 🔥 Atleast I learned that's how it's tracked for now.

Should also note that we have a lot of custom code to pre-populate the mdevs before nova-compute even starts, which is painful, hopefully that will change in the future as well now that libvirt has support for autostart in >= 7.8.0

nova has always needed to do that but sylvain has resited it for some reason.

our current code is fragile espacallly after host reboots.
currently we use the instance domain xml to persit the uuid across host reboot but
because we dont have the parent infomation we cant ensure we recarete the mdev properly after the reboot without trying to rebuild the mdev to parent mapping via inspecting the placement allcoations

sylvian and other have tried to write code to do that but it still a problem today it has not been fixed.

personally i would like to start tacking mdevs in either the pci_tracker or resources table.

if we trackted them in the pci_tracker or resouce table we would not have the reboot problem.

nova currenly choose the uuid not the host or operator so we should not get conflicts like this today.
Does this call return a list of devnames? Based on the doc it returns virNodeDevice objects. I'm wondering how then dev.startswith(devname) works in this context

we could optimize this call by checking the libvirt version in https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/ef18d36bf81755e5cca6e5257355eddfa938b615/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L8058 and passing a virtdev instead of a devname to _get_mediated_device_information there https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/ef18d36bf81755e5cca6e5257355eddfa938b615/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L8069

This would prevent iterating over all the mdevs for each of the mdevs... 
Here, you create a O(N2) complexity instead of a single O(N) loop.

Fortunately, even with large GPUs, this shouldn't be a performance impact as we could have only 128 mdevs or less per host.

i think and i would have to check that this is returnign a list of libvirt nodedev names

so we are using startrs with to ignore the parent pci info at the end of the node dev name.

We always get a list of devnames by calling this libvirt API and we already use this python binding elsewhere : 
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/ef18d36bf81755e5cca6e5257355eddfa938b615/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#L8066-L8069

I don't think the optimization makes sense for the _get_mediated_devices() method, as the mdev names in the _get_mediated_devices() are returned directly from the underlying libvirt API itself and thus they should return the host's/libvirt's name for the mdev and should not fail the lookup (at least not with a VIR_ERR_NO_NODE_DEVICE).

The worst case scenario does indeed come up when the mdevs are assigned to a domain and that domain is lacking the pci suffix. I believe that scenario arises when the driver is recreating mediated devices on restart. I think it would make sense to change that code by fetching all the mediated devices on the host and attempting to reconcile the naming differences (iirc, the domains do not see the pci suffix that was added so the reconciliation is necessary anyways).

The change of this function OK, but the callers are not updated to provide the parent parameter. Actullay the parent parameter is not used by any caller. So when nova generates a devname from uuid it will generate it without parent postfix. I guess libvirt 7.7 will not accept those names any more.

So I suggest to either:
A) pass the parent param from all caller if we are on libvirt 7.7 or newer
B) start using the dev_id as devname instead of regenerating the devname here. We already put the name of the mdev into the mdev dict at https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/838976/3/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#8078

Actually, trying to see how to fix this would mean we would need to modify the callers to either pass the parent ID or using the dev_id as you told.

This would be a large modification, but I verified which callers are pinging mdev_uuid2name() and those are :
- the reshape method when allocations are still on root RP, which would only happen with a <Stein compute. In Stein, we have the reshape but also the VGPU allocations are in the pGPU RP. So, this reshape may be impacted if and only if Stein to now computes are using libvirt 7.7, which is low-risk.
- the mdev recreation method we have in libvirt when you reboot, but we also have a open bug report https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1900800 for this. 

What I consequently propose is to accept this change for now and write a follow-up patch that would fix both callers (and eventually fixing the other bug report I mentioned).
I prefer option B, I think
I'm OK with a follow up

Alternatively we can create a separate config file (eg. glance-api-internal.conf) which contains only the option we want to override and use that file to launch the service for internal api.
This is ready for review, and is tracked for inclusion in downstream RHOSP as soon as possible, thanks!
I believe the approach with the separate file is easier for backport. With the approach we can use the shared config directory and does not need the additional service in roles data.
I considered that approach but judged it more complex to implement, especially in light of the anticipated need to backport it all.

> We can continue with this, but would need to consider adding update tasks to ensure the glance_api_internal service is enabled if glance_api service is enabled, as a safe guard.

I'm not concerned with major upgrade because users always need to regenerate roles, otherwise they can face different issues. So I don't think we require this in the change for master.
See https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/866075
Let's not reinvent a working solution unless there's a compelling reason. I've successfully tested trial backports all the way back to train, including deployments with tls-e and DCN deployments.

Reducing upgrade impact can be a reason, IMO. In case users do not update roles data during minor update, which we don't usually require, then they end up with incomplete glance services after upgrade. That's the main concern I have if we backport this to stable branches.

We can continue with this, but would need to consider adding update tasks to ensure the glance_api_internal service is enabled if glance_api service is enabled, as a safe guard.

Hmm. I noticed we can't use this approach because of tls proxy ... I'll consider how we can complete that approach separately but at this moment I don't have clear ETA. so I'm good with merging this approach now (as I said I won't block this change now but we should be quite careful about backporting this)
Adding something to tge update_tasks is a great idea, I'll pursue a follow-up patch.

deployment/glance/glance-api-edge-contai.message:
I assume this is removed because we no longer need it here. It's used to set firewall_{,ssl}edge_frontend_rules but those are now excluded (as pointed out below) since we're now using GlanceApiInternal for GlanceApiEdge.

I see EnableGlanceApiProxy is still used in haproxy-edge-container-puppet.yaml

Are these firewall rules (including the SSL version too) no longer necessary in this file because we're now using GlanceApiInternal instead of GlanceApiBase and GlanceApiInternal defines them in deployment/glance/glance-api-internal-container-puppet.yaml?
Correct. The GlanceApiInternal template defines the firewall rules, even when the template is referenced by this GlanceApiEdge template for use at edge sites.

So the GlanceApiEdge service which is deployed on certain DCN nodes (e.g. DistributedCompute or DistributedComputeHci) will result in the GlanceApiInternal service being deployed on Edge nodes without the GlanceApi (external) service. That makes sense to me since we shouldn't need the user-facing external glance service on the DCN nodes. We just need to ensure that the image services are consumed at the local edge site rather than at the central site.
Correct. Also, the service_config_settings at L76 still apply at edge sites.
This makes sense since the port can now change.
It ~shouldn't~ change (unless someone modifies the endpoint map), but I want to reduce the number of places where hard coded port numbers appear.
this parameter cannot be removed without deprecating it frist
It's removed from this file as it's no longer referenced, but the parameter is still used by haproxy-edge-container-puppet.yaml

deployment/haproxy/haproxy-edge-containe.message: glance_api_edge_uri is removed but on line 125 the glance_api_edge_uri is getattr'd from GlanceApiEdge for nova_compute. So the URI is still getting passed where it is needed so it should be OK to remove it as an output here.

I had to revert this and go back to having each service (GlanceApiEdge and HAproxyEdge) declare their own glance_api_edge_uri Heat output. This seems to be necessary because the two services are, by design, never deployed on the same edge nodes (GlanceApiEdge is deployed on the first 3 nodes, then HAproxyEdge on scale out nodes). When testing this on an actual DCN deployment, Heat threw an obscure yaql merge error when processing the HAproxyEdge template for a scale out node, and I think that's because the scale out role doesn't include the GlanceApiEdge service.
Correct. I basically de-duped things so that the glance_api_edge_uri is derived in one place (the GlanceApiEdge template), and it's referenced again here at L123 and L125.
So we're excluding the non-internal version of glance_api here.
So if EnableGlanceApiProxy is true, then glance_api_internal is true. Else False per line 95.
So these changes are just to rename it from glance_api_* to glance_api_internal_*
Correct. This is a side effect of the GlanceApiEdge service now being derived from the GlanceApiInternal service, which has its own set of node names and IPs.
We're now using the GlanceApiEdge resource above.

nodepool/elements/nodepool-base/finalise.message:
I'm reading https://networkmanager.dev/docs/admins/ and it says to drop a config file into /etc/NetworkManager/conf.d ... which seems like a better idea than trying to modify this.

The option seems OK ... I feel a sense of deja vu about this, but it was all something to do with /etc/resolv.conf being a symlink.  I thought the idea was that if /etc/resolv.conf was a file basically nothing would touch it.  But reading the comment below about that (L223), I guess what I'm tihnking about is systemd-resolved ...

getting a dedicated file seems OK - I'll still use the configparser to write it, since it's still an ini-file. I'll also ensure it's using the same name as the "base-job" patch, so that we're all good. *maybe* the base-job may also check for the existence of this file and, if present, not do anything, though at this point it's probably over-thinking.

Regarding the option: "unmanaged" value means that, whatever the file is and its content, NM won't do anything. That's precisely what we want, since we want to get only one nameserver, pointing to 127.0.0.1. Other values may lead to unwanted behavior.

https://developer-old.gnome.org/NetworkManager/stable/NetworkManager.conf.html documents this setting. rc-manager apparently indicates resolv.conf management and unmanaged is what we want since we set our own value.

 In [1]: a = "cr-lrp-c111"
 In [2]: a.strip("cr-lrp-")
 Out[2]: '111'
 
Note that the the "c" after the "-" was also stripped

I think split should be fine, otherwise you could also use replace()

For example:

 In [1]: a = "cr-lrp-c111"
 In [2]: a.replace("cr-lrp-", "", 1)
 Out[2]: 'c111'
 
That will replace only the first occurrence (if any)

However, this fix still isn't correct. You'll see in the above that I'm passing a 'scheduler_hints' keyword. Based on the previous code, I'd expect these to get combined. That isn't happening.

  REQ: curl -g -i -X POST http://10.0.109.180/compute/v2.1/servers -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "OpenStack-API-Version: compute 2.73" -H "User-Agent: openstacksdk/0.102.1 keystoneauth1/5.1.0 python-requests/2.28.1 CPython/3.8.15" -H "X-Auth-Token: {SHA256}4b70091bc538d8cb139786bb3558000cd6ba1d62870f836671b3b5eaa6f6d4ac" -H "X-OpenStack-Nova-API-Version: 2.73" -d '{"server": {"name": "foo", "min_count": 1, "networks":
 [{"uuid": "1207f309-02d5-40f7-bd37-90f08facf895"}], "imageRef": "6609a3f9-cfae-46f8-84ba-90af41f0977f", "max_count": 1, "flavorRef": "1"}, "OS-SCH-HNT:scheduler_hints": {"group": "eb1a8f8f-b8bd-4593-9a76-c147ac361c45"}}'

The relevant bit is this:

  "OS-SCH-HNT:scheduler_hints": {"group": "eb1a8f8f-b8bd-4593-9a76-c147ac361c45"}

That should look like:

  "OS-SCH-HNT:scheduler_hints": {"group": "eb1a8f8f-b8bd-4593-9a76-c147ac361c45", "different_host": []}

Something like this should do the trick:

  if 'scheduler_hints' not in kwargs:
      kwargs['scheduler_hints'] = {}
  kwargs['scheduler_hints']['group'] = group_obj['id']

Can you address this and add unit tests? Unit tests would be helpful to (a) prove the fix and (b) prevent regressions.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Traditionally we have always shipped a new set of modules with every new kernel.  The changing key ensures that the kernel and modules are properly matched.  This change would allow an old module to be used with a new kernel.  This may cause subtle hard to diagnose bugs.  

I need to know why we are doing this.  What upgrade issues are you solving? Is there a LaunchPad?  A spec?  Point me to them.

Please set a review topic, or otherwise please point me at whatever other changes relate to this change.

I do this change to prepare for such a user case:
There is no change in kernel and there are some changes in the out of tree kernel modules. If the system patch for upgrading is built on a different project than the initial one, kernel will be forced to upgrade too, or else signature verification will fail.
The only way to avoid this issue is: we build every system patch for upgrading on the same project to avoid kernel rebuilding in this user case.

So, does centos stx make patches on the same project? 
Will debian stx make patches in this way too? 

Thanks.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Adding Scott because he has some experience with this sort of thing and may have an opinion.

Email from Scott:

All official patches are built in a single persistent build environment.

Every kernel patch always rebuilds and ships all the kernel modules as well.

A kernel module patch can be built independently of the kernel due to the persistent build environment.

The CentOS Build avoidance feature allowed a designer to avoid kernel rebuilds when developing a module patch in his own dev environment.  I assume the Debian builds --reuse feature can be used the same way, but perhaps we ned to test that.

Scott
There are some more redirects at play, among them to S3.

This is actually an incomplete caching proxy because the actual galaxy tarballs are served out of amazon s3. You will need to update things to handle this like pypi or docker hub where we proxy the frontend indexing service as well as the backend distribution service.

hooks/hooks.py.message:
python-libmaas in the ppa carries 0.6.8, while the archive(s) have 0.6.4, we shouldn't be adding a new ppa to address this issue, we need to fix the package via SRU[0] or MRE[1].

[0] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/StableReleaseUpdates
[1] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/StableReleaseUpdates#New_upstream_microreleases

```
 python-libmaas | 0.6.4-0ubuntu1 | jammy/universe   | source
 python-libmaas | 0.6.4-0ubuntu1 | kinetic/universe | source
 python-libmaas | 0.6.4-0ubuntu1 | lunar/universe   | source
```
Thanks Felipe, that makes sense.  Sounds like that's the way to go, and we can revisit a ppa if an SRU is discovered to be impossible for some reason.
